At that time, the bhiká¹£us heard that the Buddha had subdued such an evil person, and each said this:

Long ago, in the country of KÄÅ›i, there was a king named Evil Receiver. He committed many unlawful acts, causing suffering to the people. He was cruel and merciless. The precious and superior goods of merchants from the four directions were all confiscated without compensation.
Because of this, the precious goods in the country eventually became very expensive. The people spread the word, and his evil reputation spread far and wide.
At that time, there was a parrot king in the forest who heard passersby speaking of the king's evil deeds. He thought to himself:
Although I am a bird, I still know what is wrong. Now I should go to him and speak of the right path.
If the king hears my words, he will surely say:
Even that bird king has good words. How can a human king be criticized by him? Perhaps he can change and improve.
He then flew high into the sky, to the king's garden, circled down, and landed on a tree.
When the king's wife entered the garden for sightseeing, the parrot flapped its wings, chirped, and said to her:

The king is now extremely tyrannical and unrighteous, harming the people, and his poison extends to birds and beasts. The cries of the living creatures fill the air, and the resentment and lamentation of humans and animals are heard throughout the world.
The queen is no different from the king. How can the parents of the people act like this?
When the queen heard this, her anger and poison flared up:
What kind of small bird is this, scolding me to my face?
She sent someone to spy and capture it.
At that time, the parrot was neither startled nor afraid, and entered the captor's hand.
When the queen obtained it, she immediately gave it to the king.
The king said to the parrot:

The parrot replied:
I am speaking of the king's unrighteousness in order to benefit him, not daring to scold him.
At that time, the king asked:
What is unrighteous?
The parrot answered:
There are seven unrighteous things that can endanger the king's body.
The king asked:

The parrot replied:
First, indulging in women without being chaste.
Second, enjoying alcohol and becoming intoxicated, neglecting state affairs.
Third, greedily playing chess, not cultivating etiquette and education.
Fourth, hunting and killing, completely lacking compassion.
Fifth, they enjoy speaking ill words and have no good speech.
Sixth, they double the taxes and punishments imposed on the people.
Seventh, they seize the people's wealth without justice.
These seven things can endanger the king's body.
There are also three things that can bring about the downfall of a kingdom.
The king asked again:
'What are the three things?'
He replied:
'First, being close to evil and deceitful people.
Second, not associating with the wise and not accepting sincere advice.
Third, enjoying conquering other countries and not caring for the people.
If these three are not eliminated, the time of downfall will come, not in the morning but in the evening.
As a ruler, the entire country looks up to you. The king should be like a bridge, crossing over the myriad people;

When the king heard these words, he deeply felt ashamed:

The Causes of the Buddha's Younger Brother Nanda Becoming a Monk and Attaining the Way (96) The Causes of the Buddha's Younger Brother Nanda Becoming a Monk and Attaining the Way The Buddha was in the country of Kapilavastu. He entered the city to beg for alms and arrived at Nanda's house. It happened that Nanda was applying makeup to his wife's eyebrows. Hearing the Buddha at the door, he wanted to go out and look. His wife made an agreement with him, saying:
When you go out to see the TathÄgata, come back in before the makeup on my forehead dries.
Nanda then went out, saw the Buddha, bowed, took the bowl to his house, filled it with food, and offered it to the Buddha.
The Buddha did not take it himself, but passed it to Ä€nanda, who also did not take it. Ä€nanda said:
From whom did you obtain the bowl? Return it to its original place.
So he took his bowl and followed the Buddha to the Nyagrodha Monastery.
The Buddha then ordered a barber to shave Nanda's hair.
Nanda was unwilling and angrily said to the barber:
You can now shave the hair of all the people of Kapilavastu.
The Buddha asked the barber:
Why won't you shave him?
He replied:
I dare not shave him out of fear.
The Buddha and Ä€nanda went to his side themselves. Because of his fear, Nanda did not dare not to shave.
Although he had his hair shaved, he always wanted to return home. The Buddha always took him along, and he was unable to leave.

Later, on one day, he was next in charge of guarding the dwelling. He was delighted, thinking, Now I have a chance to return home. I will wait until the Buddha and the assembly have all left, and then I will return home.
After the Buddha entered the city, he thought to himself:
Fill the water pots and bring them back.
He immediately drew water, but as soon as one pot was full, the other would overturn. This went on for a long time, and he could not fill the pots. He then said:
Neither can be filled. Let the monks come back and draw the water themselves. I will now just put the pots in the house and leave.
He then closed the door to the room, but as soon as he closed one panel, the other would open. As soon as he closed one door, the other would open. He thought again:
Neither can be closed. I will just leave them as they are.
Even if the monks lose their robes and other belongings, I have plenty of wealth and can make it up.
He then left the monks' quarters and thought to himself:
The Buddha will certainly come this way, so I will go by a different route.
The Buddha knew his thoughts and also came by a different route. He saw the Buddha coming from afar and hid behind a large tree.
The tree spirit lifted the tree into the sky, standing in the open air.
The Buddha saw Nanda and brought him back to the monastery, asking him:
Do you think of your wife?
He replied:
Indeed I do.
He then took Nanda to Mount AnÄpÄnas and asked him again:
Is your wife beautiful?
He replied:
She is beautiful.
In the mountains there was an old blind monkey, and he asked again:
Is your wife SundarÄ«'s face and appearance as beautiful as this monkey?
Nanda was distressed and thought to himself:
My wife is extremely beautiful, second to none among people. Why does the Buddha now compare my wife to this monkey?

The Buddha then took him to the Heaven of the Thirty-three, where they went to all the heavenly palaces to look around. They saw the celestial sons together with the celestial maidens enjoying each other's company.
He saw in one palace five hundred heavenly maidens, but no heavenly sons.
He returned and asked the Buddha, and the Buddha said:
You go yourself and ask.
Sunda went and asked, saying:
In all the palaces there are heavenly sons, but why is there no heavenly son here alone?
The heavenly maidens replied:

In JambudvÄ«pa, the Buddha's younger brother Nanda, was forced by the Buddha to go forth. Because of the causes and conditions of going forth, after his life ends he will be reborn in this heavenly palace to be our heavenly son.
Sunda replied:
I am the very one.
He then wanted to stay right there, and the heavenly maidens said:
We are heavenly beings, and you are now human. Return and give up your human lifespan, and then be reborn here, and you can stay.
He then returned to the Buddha and fully reported the above matter to the World-Honored One.
The Buddha said to Nanda:
How does your wife's beauty compare to that of the heavenly maidens?
Nanda replied:
Compared to those heavenly maidens, my wife is like a blind macaque.
The Buddha took Nanda back to JambudvÄ«pa. For the sake of being reborn in the heavens, Nanda diligently upheld the precepts.
At that time, Ä€nanda spoke a verse for him, saying:

The Buddha took Nanda and went to the hells again. He saw that all the cauldrons were boiling people, but he only saw one empty cauldron bubbling and waiting.
He wondered why it was so and came to ask the Buddha. The Buddha told him:

At that time, the country of Pancala offered five hundred white geese to King Prasenajit, who sent them to the Jetavana Monastery.
When the assembly of monks was eating, each one begged for food. The geese saw the gathering of monks and stood in front of them.
The Buddha spoke the Dharma with one voice, and sentient beings each attained understanding according to their kind.

At that time, the flock of geese also understood the Buddha's words. Hearing the Dharma, they were delighted and cried out in harmony. Later, they flew to another place, and hunters covered them with a net and killed them all.

When the net was cast, a goose cried out, and all the geese cried out in harmony. It was the sound of listening to the Dharma. Riding on this wholesome thought, they were reborn in the Heaven of the Thirty-three.
The way of being reborn in the heavens has three thoughts:
First, thinking of where they came from;
Second, thinking of where they will definitely be reborn;
Third, thinking of what karma they previously created to be reborn in the heavens.
He then thought to himself and saw his past causes. There were no other good deeds, only listening to the Dharma by the side of the Buddha and Sangha.
